title: U.K. companies for sale — at a 13% discount
text:
Buying a British company costs 13% less now than before the Brexit referendum in June 2016, according to new data from international law firm Mayer Brown.

The slump in sterling against the euro has fuelled a buying binge from buyout groups which, together with European companies, have spent £21.6 billion ($26.8 billion) over 12 months to 4 September. That compares to £11.8 billion for the same period in the previous year.

“A lot of EU buyers seem to have decided that the risks of Brexit are now quite well-understood, and that they don’t present a barrier to making acquisitions if the price is right.” James West, Mayer Brown

Foreign exchange markets have been betting heavily against sterling since July when Boris Johnson became prime minister. The British pound is expected to fall further if Johnson crashes out of the EU without an agreement.

James West, partner in the private equity practice at Mayer Brown, said despite fears of a no-deal Brexit, the low cost of buying U.K. companies is outweighing concerns.

“A lot of EU buyers seem to have decided that the risks of Brexit are now quite well-understood, and that they don’t present a barrier to making acquisitions if the price is right,” he said.

West added: “There will always be a market for high-quality businesses, regardless of what is happening in politics. If an acquisition makes strategic sense and the valuation looks attractive, a deal will be made.”

British companies which have been sold include Merlin Entertainment which was bought by a consortium including Danish Kirk Kristiansen family’s investment vehicle, the owner of Lego. German private equity firm Aurelius carved out BT’s fleet business in the U.K.

Despite the rise in interest from European buyers, the value of overseas M&A deals for U.K. companies was down 15% to £98.9 billion in the first eight months of the year. This was mainly driven by a fall in acquisitions by U.S. bidders from £83.6 billion to £49.8 billion. That data was significantly skewed by one large transaction in September 2018 — Comcast’s CMCSA, -0.69% £30 billion takeover for entertainment group Sky.
